Question: why was the shift to universal health coverage necessary
Answer: To ensure that all Kenyans have access to quality, affordable and comprehensive quality health services from health promotion to prevention, curative, rehabilitation, and palliative care without suffering financial hardship.

Question: what is social health insurance shi
Answer: It is a form of health financing mechanism based on risk and resource pooling to increase efficiency of the healthcare system that ensures that people pay for premiums into a pooled fund that can be used for those who need the services at no cost when they need the services.

Question: what are the principles of social health insurance
Answer: Accessible, quality, affordable healthcare services for all, Well-defined benefit package anchored in law, Mandatory registration and contribution, Equity.

Question: why is social health insurance important
Answer: An efficient way of managing health funds – able to set and monitor administrative costs, An equitable way of managing health funds – funding based on need, Direct contributions from beneficiaries improves participation and transparency, Constitutional provisions exist allowing for targeting of funds for specific priorities/geographical area.

Question: what are the  health laws
Answer:
1. The Social Health Insurance Law (2023) – Creating institutions and legislating the procedures for driving social health insurance in Kenya.
2. The Digital Health Act (2023) – Creating the enabling environment for development of digital platform for integrating health system needs and database for citizens for purposes of health care access.
3. Facility Improvement Financing Law (2023) – Specifically developed for public health facilities to ensure they are well financed to offer health services to Kenyans, and are well positioned to compete with private healthcare facilities.
4. Primary Care Networks Law (2023) – To create the necessary legislation for development of collaborative mechanism for related healthcare providers in the sub-county level, ensuring collaboration for service delivery and referral mechanisms.
Category: Institutions Created by UHC Laws and Transition

Question: what informs the proposed reforms towards the shi why was the transition to sha necessary instead of revamping nhif
Answer:
• The ultimate goal of a social health insurance system is to provide equitable and affordable access to healthcare services for all members of society.
• To increase health insurance coverage.
• Existence of fragmented pools targeting different populations creates inefficiencies, resulting in increased healthcare costs. SHI proposes 3 consolidated pools to address inefficiencies.
• High number of Kenyans being subjected to financial constraints due to catastrophic illnesses.
• Promote equity and fairness in contribution, through households and not individuals.
Category: Institutions Created by UHC Laws and Transition

Question: what is the difference between sha and shif
Answer: SHA is the manager of the 3 Funds: PHCF, SHIF, and ECCF. The 3 funds have different mandates and their monies have different sources. The registration of members is done by SHA.
Category: Institutions Created by UHC Laws and Transition

Question: what is the transition process from nhif to sha
Answer: Transition clause 2 (1) provides for the transfer of rights, powers, liabilities, and duties to be taken over by SHA after the effective date of the Act i.e., 22nd November 2023.
Category: Institutions Created by UHC Laws and Transition

Question: how will the transition process from nhif to sha be done
Answer: The Transition Committee, created in February 2024, will work for 6 months and the two boards (NHIF and SHA) in consultation with the Ministry of Health ensure the transition process is completed within the 12 months provided for in the law. The Committee will develop legal and institutional framework; guidelines and operational mechanism in regard to assets and liabilities, human resources and pensions and other staff benefits; and develop a clear roadmap for the winding up of NHIF by July 2024.
Category: Institutions Created by UHC Laws and Transition

Question: are the three bodies under sha independent with own structures
Answer: There will only be one authority to manage three funds under i.e., The Primary Care Fund, The Social Health Insurance Fund, and the Emergency, Chronic and Critical Illness Fund.
Category: Institutions Created by UHC Laws and Transition

Question: will the current running contracts with suppliers and health care providers be affected by the transition process
Answer: The contracts and other legal obligations of NHIF have been taken over by SHA. The transition committee will work on seamless transition of the contractual obligations to ensure uninterrupted service delivery.
Category: Institutions Created by UHC Laws and Transition

Question: are nhif assets and liabilities automatically shas
Answer: Yes, Section 2(1) of the transition provisions allows the assets and liabilities to be automatically transferred to SHA.
Category: Institutions Created by UHC Laws and Transition

Question: how will the transition process ensure continuity of services to kenyans
Answer: The SHI Regulations provide that all paid-up members and running contracts with NHIF will run until June 30th, 2024, and the SHA will take over with the new rates and benefits at 1st July 2024, hence no services will be disrupted.
Category: Institutions Created by UHC Laws and Transition

Question: what happens to contributions paid in advance by self employed persons if the means testing determine their rates to be lower or higher than ksh
Answer: The SHA will inform the beneficiary of the difference between what is paid and the difference which is supposed to be topped up for the year if less than the required premium, or roll over to the subsequent year if in surplus.
Category: Institutions Created by UHC Laws and Transition

Question: how will the healthcare contracts be seamlessly transitioned in view of the new benefit package
Answer: New contracts under SHA will be issued to empaneled healthcare providers under section 33(3) of the SHI Law 2023.
Category: Institutions Created by UHC Laws and Transition

Question: will we remain our regionalbranch network
Answer: Branch and Regional Network will be determined by the requirements of the SHI under the SHA Act 2023.
Category: Institutions Created by UHC Laws and Transition

Question: will there be rebranding of the new entities once they come on board
Answer: The Boards of each entity established under the UHC Laws will develop their own distinct brands according to needs.
Category: Institutions Created by UHC Laws and Transition

Question: what happens to the ict infrastructure
Answer: The current infrastructure automatically changes ownership to the SHA Board, and retention of the same will be on needs basis. For retiring infrastructure, Public Procurement and Assets Disposal Act provisions will be used for disposing them off.
Category: Institutions Created by UHC Laws and Transition

Question: how will staff be affected by the transition process
Answer: SHA will recruit their own staff in line with the approved organizational establishment. 6(3) allows NHIF qualified staff to apply for declared vacancies. 6(4) will have staff undergo a process to gauge their suitability and thereby transition to SHA on a priority basis. 5(a)(b) allows staff to retire or be redeployed elsewhere in the public services respectively.

Question: what happens to staff who will not be absorbed by the sha
Answer: The law and ILO procedures allow that no current employees of NHIF will be disadvantaged during the transition process. Hence those who will not be absorbed by the SHA will either transit to the public service or retire willingly.

Question: in the event that sha remuneration package is lower than that of nhif how will this impact the transitioned staff
Answer: The employment and labour laws are very clear on this. The salary of the employees under SHA will be binding as it is a newly established legal entity.

Question: what becomes of the staff pension contributions for staff who transition to sha and those who are deployed to other public service sectors
Answer: Matters of pension are highly regulated under Retirement Benefits Authority (RBA) and continuity on scheme contributions and benefits will not be lost by NHIF staff during transition.

Question: will the union be fully involved in the transition process
Answer: Unions will be involved during transition by both the Transition Committee and NHIF and SHA boards. Non-unionized officers of NHIF will also be represented and their concerns taken care of.

Question: will there be forced exits
Answer: Under the SHI Act, there is no provision for forced retirement.

Question: what is primary health care
Answer: It is essential health care based on practical, scientifically sound and socially acceptable methods and technology that is made universally accessible to individuals and families in the community.
Category: Primary Health Care & the PHC Fund

Question: what is primary health care fund
Answer: The fund shall be used to purchase primary healthcare services from health facilities.
Category: Primary Health Care & the PHC Fund

Question: who is eligible to access the primary healthcare fund
Answer: All persons residing in Kenya.
Category: Primary Health Care & the PHC Fund

Question: how will i register for the primary healthcare fund
Answer: Registration for Social Health Insurance will be an automatic registration for the Primary Healthcare Fund.
Category: Primary Health Care & the PHC Fund

Question: will i have to contribute to the primary healthcare fund what other sources of funds are there
Answer: No, there will be no individual contributions to the Primary Healthcare Fund. The main source of funding will be allocation from the government and grants.
Category: Primary Health Care & the PHC Fund

Question: when will i use the primary healthcare fund
Answer: When visiting level 2,3 facilities or upon referral by community health promoters, where patients will be treated for free.
Category: Primary Health Care & the PHC Fund

Question: what is the maximum amount the primary healthcare fund can cover
Answer: The expenditure incurred on the fund shall be limited to annual budget estimates prepared by the authority at the beginning of the financial year to which they relate.
Category: Primary Health Care & the PHC Fund

Question: what is the emergency chronic and critical illness fund
Answer: This is a fund established to provide money to pay the costs of management of chronic illnesses after depletion of the SHI over and to cover the costs of emergency treatment.
Category: Emergency, Chronic, and Critical Illness Fund

Question: who will be eligible to register to the emergency chronic and critical illness fund
Answer: An individual registered to the Social Health Authority will be able to access medical services under the Emergency, Chronic and Critical Illness Fund.
Category: Emergency, Chronic, and Critical Illness Fund

Question: when will i start benefiting from the emergency chronic and critical illness fund
Answer: Upon lapsing of an individual’s benefit limits under the Social Health Insurance Fund.
Category: Emergency, Chronic, and Critical Illness Fund

Question: how will my benefit package look like in the emergency chronic and critical illness fund
Answer: The healthcare services specified in the essential benefits package provided in the fourth schedule of the SHI Regulations 2024.
Category: Emergency, Chronic, and Critical Illness Fund

Question: which institution will be responsible for management of the emergency chronic and critical illness fund
Answer: The Social Health Authority has been established for the management of Social Health Insurance in Kenya. The expenditure incurred on the Fund shall be limited to annual budget estimates prepared by the Authority at the beginning of the financial year to which they relate.
Category: Emergency, Chronic, and Critical Illness Fund

Question: who will be eligible to register for sha
Answer: Every Kenyan as well as non-Kenyans residing in Kenya is eligible and will be required to register.

Question: do i need to register afresh as an sha member if i was already an nhif member
Answer: Yes.

Question: will there be any costs associated with registering afresh
Answer: None.

Question: can individuals choose not to be part of social health insurance
Answer: No. It is a mandatory requirement.

Question: will nhif members automatically transition to be sha members what of the payments that were already paid by members
Answer: NHIF members will have to register afresh with SHA. Regarding already paid contributions, the Transition Committee will provide the detailed guidelines but it is expected that there shall not be any problem between the transitions of current contributions to the new means testing- generated contribution rates.

Question: how will i register for shi
Answer: The application shall be made by filling SHA form and shall be accompanied by: (a) a copy of the national identification document of the applicant; or (b) in the case of a person without a national identification document, any other document as may be approved by the authority.

Question: how do i add dependents and are there limits on the number of children
Answer: Dependents will be declared during registration and those born after registered within 14 days after birth. There will be no limits to the number of children under a contributor.

Question: does it cover more than one wife
Answer: Yes, the SHI Act provides for more than one spouse provided that the total income of all spouses and members is captured for purposes of premium determination.

Question: if registration is per household does it mean only one spouse contributes
Answer: The decision of the person within the household to contribute premiums will be decided by the household members for the case of non-salaried members, and will be deducted from each salaried member if under salaried employment.

Question: what happens to the dependents if a member passes on
Answer: The member is required to notify the Social Health Authority in case of a demise of a dependent or contributor's demise accompanied by the death notification documents.

Question: what happens to the current biometric that are captured
Answer: All members will be required to register and get their biometrics taken afresh when the SHI kicks in.

Question: who will be the contributors to social health authority
Answer: Every Kenyan household, a non-Kenyan resident, ordinarily residing in Kenya for a period exceeding 12 months, the national government, county governments, and any other employer/donor can contribute to the SHA.

Question: how will i contribute to sha
Answer: In the case of a household whose income is derived from salaried employment, by a monthly statutory deduction from the wages or salary by the employer. In the case of a household whose income is derived from informal employment, an annual advance contribution will be made to the SHA.

Question: how much will i contribute to sha
Answer: The rate of contributions is 2.75% of individual and household income.

Question: concerning the  what happens when the two heads of a household have separate incomes
Answer: The combined income for multiple members of a household will be subjected to the 2.75% contribution based on the combined income.

Question: if both spouses are employed are both required to make monthly contributions
Answer: Yes.

Question: who is required to pay the minimum contribution of kes per month
Answer: Those whom the means testing tool determine to fall in or below contributions of Ksh 300 will contribute the base premium of Ksh 300. The government will contribute for those who apply for subsidy if falling below this threshold.

Question: is there an option for capping the deductions
Answer: Deductions are not capped.

Question: how will the determination of income for the informal sector be done
Answer: Means Testing will be used to determine proxy income based on expenditure patterns.

Question: should members wait until means testing is conducted to make contributions
Answer: For salaried employees, contributions will be based on their salaried income. However, for non-salaried income earners, contributions will only be determined using the means testing hence payment will be after means testing.

Question: if someone transitions or there is a change of income who is responsible for determining the contribution what is the reporting mechanism
Answer: The contributor will be required to notify the Social Health Authority on any change in income and they will be informed of the new contribution rates by the authority.

Question: are kenyans contributing to all three funds and how do these contributions work
Answer: No. The Primary Healthcare Fund and the Emergency Chronic and Critical Illness Fund will be publicly funded through government budget allocations and available to registered SHA members, while direct contributions will be made to the Social Health Insurance Fund.

Question: how many times will i contribute to shi
Answer: For salaried/payroll employment households, monthly contributions; For non-payroll households whose income is not derived from salary, by an annual contribution as determined by the means testing instrument.

Question: will services be accessible if i lose employment formal vs informal
Answer: No, as long as the authority is notified and new contribution arrangements agreed and honored by the contributors.

Question: is insurance premium financing available for those who cannot afford consistent payments
Answer: Premium financing will be available for those who want to access it in the non-salaried segment. For affordability, the Authority will determine and attach only premiums which the contributor can afford.

Question: can cooperative societies join sha as groups and make base minimum contributions
Answer: Yes, this is possible.

Question: what if i am unable to paycontribute to shi
Answer: In the case of households in need of financial assistance as determined by the means testing instrument, the government will subsidize at a rate apportioned from funds appropriated by Parliament and County Assemblies for that purpose.

Question: which facilities will be contracted and empaneled by sha
Answer: A health care provider or a health facility seeking to be contracted under the Social Health Insurance Fund shall make an application to the body responsible for accreditation for quality assurance in the manner prescribed by the regulations.

Question: how will i know which facilities or providers around a given area of residence will be covered by sha
Answer: The authority shall, publish on its website and in such other manner as the Authority may deem appropriate, declare the health service providers and healthcare facilities to be contracted for.

Question: what happens to my current contributions to nhif
Answer: All contributions made will be transferred to the Social Health Authority.

Question: can i choose my healthcare providers and facilities under sha
Answer: Yes.

Question: how will sha benefit lowincome and vulnerable populations and plwd
Answer: In the case of households in need of financial assistance as determined by the means testing instrument, by the government at a rate apportioned from funds appropriated by Parliament and County Assemblies.

Question: are there penalties for defaulters andor late payment
Answer: Any person who fails to pay any contribution in respect of any period on or before the day on which payment is due shall be liable to a penalty equal to two percent (2%) of the amount due of the contribution for the period in which the contribution remains unpaid and the total annual contributions.

Question: how do i pay penalties
Answer: The SHA board will provide guidance on how members will pay penalties.

Question: can i get refunded if i do not utilize my contribution
Answer: No. Premiums from all contributors will be pooled and utilized to pay health services for those who are in need of them.

Question: can i take a private health insurance cover
Answer: Yes, a beneficiary of the fund can still register for private insurance as complementary to the Social Health Insurance.

Question: for civil servants including hcws what will happen to their enhanced scheme
Answer: All Kenyans will be entitled to the same benefit package irrespective of their place and nature of work. Payments will be pegged on income hence transitioning from wage employment to pension will pay the prescribed rate for the same benefit package.

Question: are civil servants cushioned to seek services from private facilities
Answer: SHA benefits can be accessed in all types of facilities; Public, private, and FBO. Enhanced covers can be provided by the employer on top of the SHA benefits.

Question: what will happen to the school children who were covered under edu afya
Answer: The children will be covered under SHA as beneficiaries of their households.

Question: what is the package for those who opt to retireexit public service
Answer: All Kenyans will be entitled to the same benefit package irrespective of their place and nature of work. Payments will be pegged on income hence transitioning from wage employment to pension will pay the prescribed rate for the same benefit package.

Question: will sha cover travel health insurance
Answer: No.

Question: when will i use my social health insurance fund
Answer: When referred to a level 4, 5, or 6 facility or an empaneled healthcare provider.

Question: how will my benefit package look like in sha
Answer: A schedule of benefits attributable to each member of the SHA will be published and made available to each member as provided.

Question: how do the sha benefits compare with the nhif benefits
Answer: SHA benefits are more enhanced, explicit and expansive compared to the previous NHIF benefits.

Question: how can additional services be added to the essential benefits package
Answer: The SHI Act Regulations provides for a form for interested parties to make an appeal to the Benefits and Tariffs Authority to be considered for inclusion or exclusion.

Question: what happens to retired civil servants under sha
Answer: Like other Kenyans, they will be new retirees and will need to notify SHA of the change in income and hence will be informed of the new premiums and modalities of paying for them.

Question: how does the essential benefits package impact premiums
Answer: Change in the benefit package will automatically have impact on the amount of funds required to fund the new package, and hence the premiums attributable to each household will change accordingly.

Question: how does one get to know what tariffs are in use
Answer: Tariffs are published in the Regulations Schedule.

Question: which facilities will one access the sha services where do i access services
Answer: Health Providers contracted by SHA.

Question: is there a waiting period to access services
Answer: No waiting period.

Question: can one receive phc services in referral hospitals
Answer: No, only facilities contracted to offer PHC services will offer such services, basically in the category of Levels 2, 3, and 4.

Question: what happens when one falls sick when far from the selected facility
Answer: Levels 2-3 services will be sought within the assigned Network (PCN), and there will be mechanisms for one PCN to reimburse for a member who accesses services in another PCN not assigned to, but within limits of the member's PCN. Levels 4-6 will be accessed through a robust referral system from one level to another.

Question: there is a need for measures to enhance the quality of care including the role of counties in preventive services
Answer: The Quality-of-Care Bill is underway to optimize service delivery and assure quality of health services.

Question: where should providers claim payment of pending bills
Answer: SHA has absorbed all NHIF liabilities, therefore providers should claim from SHA.

Question: what will be the role of sha in ensuring commodities are available in healthcare facilities
Answer: SHA will reimburse healthcare providers based on the service provided including medicines and procedures, and the service providers have a responsibility of ensuring they have capacity to offer the same.

Question: how can individuals in kenya file complaints or seek assistance under social health authority
Answer: The Social Health Authority will develop a complaint resolution mechanism in line with guidelines of the Mwongozo code of governance for state corporations.

Question: which takes precedence between procurement tribunal and sha tribunal in procurement disputes when contracting and empanelment
Answer: The Public Procurement Tribunal as provisioned takes precedence for all public procurements as defined in the Public Procurement and Assets Disposal Act.
